awd_titl_txt: Volcanic jet noise: Linking field and laboratory experiments
awd_abstract_narration:
Volcanic eruptions are dynamic and complex, making both monitoring and understanding their source processes challenging. Infrasound, or low frequency sound waves, is becoming increasingly used to monitor and study volcanic eruptions. Volcanic jets are prolific producers of volcanic jet noise, the sound produced by turbulent flow from a volcanic vent. Volcanic jet noise was heard extensively during the 2018 Kilauea East Rift Zone eruption. Despite its increasing use, many questions on volcanic jet noise remain. The investigators will perform a systematic set of linked field and laboratory experiments to address fundamental questions on volcanic jet noise and assumptions typically made when interpreting volcano infrasound data. The lab experiments will be performed at the unique facility of project collaborator LMU (Munich, Germany) that can reproduce gas and particle jets under controlled source parameters. At Stromboli Volcano, Italy, the researchers will examine jetting from eruptions and determine the jet noise radiation pattern. The observations from the lab and field will be used to interpret and determine source parameters (e.g. jet velocity and flux) for eruptions at both Kilauea and Stromboli, as well as previously collected volcano infrasound data. The project results will have significant implications for hazard monitoring at volcano observatories in Alaska and Hawaii, the results will be presented to the general public in those regions, and broad international collaboration and training will occur. 

This project will integrate unique lab and field observations of volcanic jet noise to provide new insight into volcanic eruptions. The lab experiments will, for the first time, simulate the generation of volcanic jet noise while varying sound-influencing parameters such as particle concentration, particle shape, vent geometry, temperature, and Mach number. The field experiment at Stromboli Volcano, Italy will address the assumed highly directional nature of volcanic jet noise using advantageous topography and reliable eruptive activity, as well as providing critical corresponding high-speed visual and infrared imagery. The investigators will also capitalize on near-source infrasound and visual data collected during the 2018 Kilauea fissure eruption. By combining these three data sets, the researchers will determine the principal features and complexities of volcanic jet noise, including the characteristic frequency spectra, highly directional sound radiation, and unique waveform characteristics. These analyses will help determine 1) new scaling laws relating jet velocity to acoustic power and 2) improved eruption source constraints such as particle content and jet diameter, thus having direct implications for understanding and monitoring of volcanic eruptions worldwide. 

This award is cofunded by the Prediction of and Resilience against Extreme Events (PREEVENTS) program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Volcanic eruptions produce notable acoustic waves, often at low frequencies termed infrasound. Previous research has shown that the sound from sustained volcanic eruptions resembles a low frequency form of the noise from jet engines, termed jet noise. In this project we used a combination of field and laboratory data to better understand volcanic jet noise and how it can be used to derived eruption source parameters and improve hazard monitoring.

A significant portion of our research at the University of Alaska Fairbanks focused on the acoustic signals from the impactful 2018 eruption of Kilauea, Hawaii. The erupting fissures at Kilauea produced volcanic jet noise that was captured by nearby infrasound sensors. We constructed algorithms to quantitatively detect and characterize these signals and determine whether the source was a volcanic jet or some other process. This research was also applied successfully to eruptions at other volcanoes. Next we conducted an in-depth study of the source of the Kilauea fissure eruption infrasound. We found that the lava fountain from Fissure 8 produced jet noise signals that produced a gradual but detectable change in peak frequency and sound pressure levels. We modeled these changes as a result of a decrease in lava fountain height and hence jet velocity, as well as an increase in fountain diameter. Our model provides a method to estimate volcanic jet (fountain) properties from infrasound data, which was one of the main initial goals of our project.

Together with our collaborators we performed multiple laboratory scale and volcano data collection experiments. The laboratory scale data showed that volcanic crater shape and ash particle content do in fact affect the acoustics and should be taken into for volcanic eruptions. The effect of ash particles is significant but complex. We also collected data from Stromboli Volcano, Italy to compare to the laboratory experiments and better understand volcanic jet noise. Using novel deployments of sensors on Uncrewed Aerial System (UAS) we were better able to constrain the volcano acoustic source process. We found that ash-rich eruptions at Stromboli often have different characteristics (e.g. lower amplitude, diminished high frequencies) compared to gas-rich eruptions, and that volcanic explosions have different acoustic radiation patterns than jetting events.

We also took advantage of the once-in-a-century eruption of Hunga, Tonga in 2022 and analyzed regional and global acoustic records. This analysis revealed important aspects of acoustic wave generation, propagation, and coupling into the ionosphere, solid earth, and oceans. The unique recordings from this eruption generated widespread interest from the broader scientific community and public and increased the global impact of our scientific results and outreach.

Throughout this project we emphasized collaboration and sharing of our results with colleagues at volcano observatories in Hawaii and Alaska. The lessons learned and algorithms developed were shared with the observatories and will be used during future eruptions. Training of two PhD students also occurred, and we had numerous successful outreach events to the public.
